Award.AwardTitle: Conference Support: 12th US National Congress on Computational Mechanics; Raleigh, North Carolina; July 2013

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This grant provides funds to help organize the 2013 US National Congress on Computational Mechanics (USNCCM). The conference will take place on October 10-12, 2011 at Raleigh, North Carolina. The USNCCM conference facilitates the exchange of information on all aspects of computational engineering and science and provides a forum for discussion, education, and recognition of the talents of the computational engineering and science community. The USNCCM conference promotes the development and strengthening of the interfaces between various disciplines in engineering, sciences, and mathematics.

The 2012 2013 US National Congress on Computational Mechanics will host a student paper/presentation contest and actively seek the participation of groups underrepresented in science and engineering for participation. The funds provided will support undergraduate, graduate, and post-doctoral students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project provided travel support for participants at the 12th US National Congress on Computational Mechanics. Travel awards were provided for undergraduate students, graduate students, and postdoctoral fellows. The Congress was distinct from earlier Congresses in a couple of key ways that focused on student participation and career development. The first concerns the establishment of a computational mechanics recruiting zone whereprospective employers can met with prospective employees. Students were able to showcase their work through a poster competition and session, with posters on display in the main entryway of the convention center. Finally, a plenary panel discussion, featuring successful individuals from a broad range of backgrounds in computational mechanics was held. The focus of the plenary panel was to provide career advice to young researchers in computational mechanics. The travel support provided by this project were thus seen as being integral to ensuring broad participation by students at arguably the premier Congress in their field.

The intellectual merit of this project was manifested in several ways.  The US National Congress on Computational Mechanics provided an in depth coverage of many areas of mechanics through an interdisciplinary approach involving solids, fluids, multifunctional materials, numerical methods, and multiscale analysis. The event has become a premier conference in the field of Computational Science and Engineering, not only in the United States but also internationally. It encompasses a broad range of disciplines and has evolved into a confluence of multidisciplinary ideas. For students and post-doctoral researchers, this was an ideal platform for exposure to the state of the art developments in a broad range of fields. The conference provided an excellent platform for younger researchers to showcase their ideas andresearch progress, to experts in various fields and gain instant recognition.

The broader impacts of this project stem largely from the participation of the students and post-doctoral fellows.  Individuals supported by this project participated through presentations in technical sessions and a poster contest. The posters were displayed in the main entryway of the convention center, during a period in which regular sessions were closed.   The posters  interfaced with a computational mechanics recruiting zone, where participants could meet with prospective employees. Furthermore, a plenary panel discussion was held with experts from a diverse set of backgrounds and experiences in science and administration.  The panelists provided attendees with their insights and career advice.  The organizing committee encouraged participation from under-represented groups in this project by awarding travel scholarships and promoting their active participation in the event.
